summary: Please let this week’s episode be a calm shopping adventure
body:
Please let this week’s episode be a calm shopping adventure

I have been vibrating for a month now and I just need these stupid children to be chill for just a couple of hours. No more ghosts and blood pacts and breaking pirate law. I am done. I am getting heart palpitations. My heart is failing from anxiety every week.

Please @MatthewMercer. I need you to lock these idiots in a room and make them have nice conversations and do literally nothing else.

summary: Uhhh we can send ships? 🔥 Fjorester
question: Uhhh we can send ships? 🔥 Fjorester
answer: you absolutely can! Fjorester is cute, I love the way you can see Travis realize that Laura is making his character fall in love with hers. My controversy is this; I think it would be healthier for Jester to explore love in different places. She fell for basically the first person that was nice to her and I’d love to see her maybe grow out of him in a way? Explore her other options in this great big world, and maybe later fall in love the way people who know each other very well do.

summary: Monster Analysis: Dashilla the Sea Fury
title: Monster Analysis: Dashilla the Sea Fury
body:
Thanks to @ornerine for this art piece! See the original at https://twitter.com/ornerine/status/1070938143656951809

  • Encounter Appearance: 2-44 The Diver’s Grave
  • Armor Class 15
  • Speed 50 ft (swimming)
  • Legendary Actions, Lair Actions
  • 257 damage taken, 3 HP Remaining

Where once the waters rolled calmly by, where ocean’s heart did sing,
There stalked a lass with a hungry eye and claws that grasp and wring.

With lantern lure of a glimmer pot, with treasure in their eyes,
Below they swam to the gold they thought would await them as their prize.

Yet each of them went to surely die, their graves to not be found
For Dashilla and her hungry eye collects the lost and drowned.

Read more at critrolestats.com

summary: I don't know why people say the Nein let Dashilla go, that they should have tried to kill here.  I don't know what episode you...
body: I don’t know why people say the Nein let Dashilla go, that they should have tried to kill here. I don’t know what episode you were watching but beau, nott, and cadeuces went after her but couldn’t catch her once they were distracted by the ghost. She could fully move on their turns as a legendary action and dash on her own unhindered by the water while they could only move half speed, there’s no way they could have caught her. They didn’t let her go, she escaped. Yes, they probably should have tried to destroy the alter so she couldn’t sink more ships (or at least not do the work for her) but it’s hard to think on the air, what are you gonna do. I get that it’s annoying that a sea monster who attacks sailors without distinction is not the best thing for a party to do in dnd but there was no way to catch her no matter what they did.

summary:
[Spoilers for C2E44]

 Here it is! My entirely-too-long break down of pretty much everything that came out of Liam O’Brien’s...
body:
[Spoilers for C2E44]

Here it is! My entirely-too-long break down of pretty much everything that came out of Liam O’Brien’s mouth pertaining to the blood sacrifice/pact at the end of last week’s episode. 

Before we begin, I want to be clear that this is an analysis specifically about Caleb’s perspective during the scene in question. My thoughts about the scene as a whole, and Fjord’s role in it–and how that influences Caleb’s part in it–are more complicated (and I’ve already written about it a bit). Caleb’s motivations in this scene were obviously unhealthy, but I don’t think that Fjord was without agency or fault in this exchange, and I think that Fjord had equally complicated motivations as Caleb (if not necessarily as consciously manipulative).

This is pretty much just a paragraph-by-paragraph analysis of what Liam said on Talks Tuesday night, so I’ll be quoting chunks of it and then dumping my thoughts all over it. (And it’s below a cut because of my classic verbosity). 

And away we go!

Liam: Caleb, in that moment, could see this man, who he spent all this time with start to be tempted by power, which was always a thought that Caleb had. But he saw Fjord–not just try to figure out his father figure, or his past, or what the situation is. He saw this guy who seemed like […] he was an upright guy […] be tempted by power.

First and foremost, I find it interesting that to Caleb there is a distinction between Fjord’s power-seeking when it’s tied to learning more about himself or his past, and Fjord seeking (and being tempted by) power for power’s sake. It’s an understandable distinction to make, but it also reveals something about how Caleb views/understands power, and its acquisition. When Fjord was seeking power and knowledge as a way to learn more about his past, there was a specific, bounded purpose in his pursuit. That was, and is, a motivation that Caleb can relate to–after all, his own pursuit of power is largely motivated by him wanting to save his family from his own terrible decision. I think that Fjord’s desire for power has always been at least partially self-interested (or: Fjord’s interested in power because he spent so much of his life feeling powerless). But between Caleb projecting his understanding of power onto Fjord, and the fact that Caleb thinks of Fjord as a fundamentally “upright guy,” he hasn’t really seen the darker parts of Fjord until now.

And in that moment–[Caleb]’s very much like Trent, the man who molded him–saw for a split second in time a hunger in this guy’s eyes, and thought that it could be molded or bent for his use.

A man who has put no bounds on his pursuit of power–who does not know where his desire and temptation begins and ends–is a person who is both dangerous and vulnerable in Caleb’s view. Caleb deeply and intimately knows what it is to be Dangerous and Vulnerable. I’ve spent the past week turning the word “manipulative” around in my head. So much, that I went to look at its denotative definition.

adjective: manipulative

1. characterized by unscrupulous control of a situation or person.

I don’t disagree that Caleb (thought he) was manipulating Fjord in this moment, but I don’t think it was the favor that was the “unscrupulous” part of the manipulation. After all, while Fjord may be a man of his word, he is also on the whole (in Caleb’s mind), a Good Man. Caleb knows that it’s entirely likely that if he asks Fjord for the wrong thing he could refuse to go along with it, regardless of any pact or promise, (as Liam said, “You know, Fjord could murder Caleb later”). Caleb’s conscious goal in manipulating Fjord’s curiosity to his advantage was to obtain a favor, but the real danger of the moment was that by indulging Fjord, Caleb pushed him that much closer to the edge that Fjord has been steadily approaching over the course of this arc. Caleb doesn’t realize that the Mighty Nein genuinely care for him and want to support him, so while Caleb intended to “win” a favor from the Fjord, the real effect of Caleb’s decision to join Fjord in the sacrifice had more to do with pushing Fjord closer to being the type of person who might honor a morally questionable request.

The transactional lens through which Caleb tends to view his relationships is usually passive. It’s an instinctual derivation of his training from Trent–“the man who molded him.” This moment with Fjord is one of the first times since The Iron Shepherd’s arc that he’s actively viewed a party member through the same lens Trent viewed the Blumenthal kids. Instead of Caleb’s typical “I don’t understand how friends work,” brand of “manipulation,” this scene had Caleb think, “I am actively exploiting a weakness to my own ends.” (With a healthy serving of “I don’t know how friends work” on the side.) Caleb’s transactional understanding of interpersonal relationships has been a consistent piece of his characterization. And because it’s a perspective that’s been trained into his subconscious–and Caleb has consistently resisted any desire to move towards recovery–it’s a perspective that’s hard to break out of. But up until the most recent episode, the person who was most harmed by this outlook was Caleb himself.

He thought, “I could take a risk here, that will probably be okay. I could probably do this and not end the world, or anything. We could pull short of whatever this is going to be, and I could have a new understanding with Fjord, and I could probably pull a favor out of this.” I thought that in advance, like “[Fjord] wants to do something here, and I want to facilitate it, and have him be beholden to me for it.”

While Caleb went into the blood sacrifice with the intention and expectation that they wouldn’t see it through to its end, in the moment he ultimately leaves the decision in Fjord’s hands. When Caleb is given opportunity and reason to draw the exchange to a close, he instead pushes Fjord in order to see how far he’s willing to go in his pursuit. If the exchange had ended there, with Caleb deciding they ought to leave well enough alone, he would have still walked away with his favor. But I don’t know that they would have come to the same “understanding.” And to Caleb’s mind, it’s possible that Fjord hadn’t yet reached a point where he was “beholden” to Caleb. That final acquisition to Fjord might have been enough to tip the scales.

Caleb’s relationship with Fjord is distinct from the individual relationships he has with the rest of the group. They are more alike than I think the both of them realize. To the extent that they do realize it though, their similar approaches to solving problems has always been their most common point of connection. The extent to which Caleb and Fjord clearly don’t understand each other has also been one of their biggest points of contention. While I don’t think most of the party (outside of Nott) necessarily trusts Caleb, I think at this point most of them believe that he’s dedicated to the group. I think Fjord has come closer to reaching that point over the course of this arc, but I don’t know if he’d quite arrived there yet. Fjord has been burned and betrayed by people often enough that he likely places more stock in actions than he does in words. Caleb helping to save him from the Iron Shepherds, and putting himself on the line in Dark Tow are really the biggest examples of Caleb acting in support of Fjord/the group. Even if Caleb doesn’t fully understand Fjord’s stance on loyalty, I think he at least understands that he values action over words. It’s a risk to put the call of whether or not to continue the ritual in Fjord’s hands, but that very abdication of control increases the chance that Fjord will recognize Caleb’s sacrifice (both literally and metaphorically) as something that warrants or constitutes a debt between them. Putting the decision in Fjord’s hands also lets Caleb poke and prod at the edges of Fjord’s interest in power.

But even within the depths of Caleb’s manipulative inner monologue, a bit of sentimentality slips through. There are many things that Caleb wanted out of the exchange, most of them seemingly one-sided. But Liam lists “an understanding with Fjord,” as a distinct motivating factor. Maybe I’m reading too much into that particular word choice (but hey, that’s what I do), but I think it’s important that Caleb was looking for an understanding with Fjord, and not an understanding of or from Fjord. (Whereas I think Fjord was seeking an understanding of Caleb, just as much as he was interested in finding an understanding with Caleb.) I think that Caleb often feels like he’s on his back foot with Fjord–he hasn’t found the awkward harmony and equilibrium with him that he has with the other members of the group. They understand each other on a pragmatic level, and they both honestly like and care for the other, but there hasn’t really been mutual understanding there. And sadly, despite Fjord’s declaration that “we understand each other,” at the end, I don’t think they found it in this scene, either. For Fjord, that understanding was bound up in the symbolism of their joined hands. But, “Caleb saw no significance to cut palms touching, other than the fact that it was obvious that Fjord did.” It’s actually quite astounding that Caleb understands enough about Fjord to know that making a deliberate and definitive display of solidarity would work toward winning Fjord’s loyalty (or: would make him beholden to him), without understanding the personal and emotional significance that Fjord brings to his loyalties. I do think that Caleb and Fjord both came out of the pact with a greater understanding of each other, and how far the other is willing to go in the pursuit of power and its “reward.” But I don’t think they found a common point of understanding between each other.

I am also struck by the fact that this scene marks one of the first times Caleb has experienced remorse since he killed his parents.

[A]fter that moment, […] Caleb was disgusted with himself […] He was a product of his schooling in that moment. And part of him was like “Yes,” and the rest of him went, “You fucking piece of filth. Look at you.”

I think that there’s a lot that Caleb regrets, or that he doesn’t feel great about, but in general Caleb tends not to be particularly reflective about his darker impulses/instincts. Caleb defaults to “manipulating” the people around him, because he legitimately doesn’t know how to have interpersonal relationships that don’t involve some element of duplicity or calculated reciprocity. Similarly, he’s willing and able to be intimidating and coldly calculating when he needs to be, because those are skills and modes of operating that have become his normal. The nature of his transactional relationship towards other characters has always been predicated on relatively small, but steady demonstrations of support and power. The blood sacrifice/pact marks the first time that Caleb has chosen to manipulate his relationship with a member of the Nein via the explicit exploitation of their vulnerabilities. It’s the first time Caleb has actively approached a situation through Trent’s perspective as opposed to solving problems with Trent’s methods.

At the moment, Caleb is at a crossroads. On the one hand, the intense amount of regret, disgust and self-loathing he experienced right after making the pact with Fjord–coupled with Jester’s disappointment–may trigger an honest reckoning with himself. It might not be an immediate shift, but if some combination of Beau, Nott, and Jester are able to get him to actually be honest about his motivations and feelings, there is some potential for healthy progress. On the other hand, Caleb may (and, honestly, probably will) interpret this scene as a confirmation of his deepest suspicions that he is a “garbage person.” He might close off and refuse to engage with the others. Caleb often seems to embody a, “I’m a terrible person, may as well embrace it,” mindset where it comes to morals. If his sense of self becomes more negative after this moment, it may result in him making increasingly dubious and harmful decisions. I really have no clue what road lies ahead of this, only that it’s probably going to be really fucking painful.

Some additional thoughts that aren’t as directly related to everything above:

Liam: Ultimately he knew he would get to a point where–There’s things that he wants to do, and there’s multiple things that he might do. He’s not quite sure what he wants to do, but he has a couple of branches of things that he could do.

I really want Caleb to actually talk to the group about these branching plans, because while what I ultimately want for Caleb is for him to move on, I’m also really curious about whether the group might be able to help him find a solution that poses relatively little risk to reality, saves his parents, and allows him to maintain the relationship with the group. I don’t think that specific outcome is particularly likely. But regardless, I think the fact that Caleb’s goals are still relatively malleable means that there’s a chance to alter them.

None of those are going to happen unless he takes risks, and earns big. So there’s no reason to play it safe, after a certain point. Calculated risks, something that Caleb and Fjord have talked about for a long time. And if he dies trying to do the things he’s attempting here? That’s okay with him. He is trying to undo something disgusting and terrible. He’s willing to put his life on the line to make it happen. So he doesn’t do anything willy-nilly–he thinks, “Well this could be the end of you, but it could get you this much closer to– […] this could pull you closer to the thing you want.”

Hey, fuck me, Caleb will literally throw his life away on the slim chance he might be able to bring his parents back instead of trying to build a new one with these people who already and also love him.

[Spoilers for C2E44]

Here it is! My entirely-too-long break down of pretty much everything that came out of Liam O’Brien’s mouth pertaining to the blood sacrifice/pact at the end of last week’s episode. 

Before we begin, I want to be clear that this is an analysis specifically about Caleb’s perspective during the scene in question. My thoughts about the scene as a whole, and Fjord’s role in it–and how that influences Caleb’s part in it–are more complicated (and I’ve already written about it a bit). Caleb’s motivations in this scene were obviously unhealthy, but I don’t think that Fjord was without agency or fault in this exchange, and I think that Fjord had equally complicated motivations as Caleb (if not necessarily as consciously manipulative).

This is pretty much just a paragraph-by-paragraph analysis of what Liam said on Talks Tuesday night, so I’ll be quoting chunks of it and then dumping my thoughts all over it. (And it’s below a cut because of my classic verbosity). 

And away we go!

[[MORE]]

Liam: Caleb, in that moment, could see this man, who he spent all this time with start to be tempted by power, which was always a thought that Caleb had. But he saw Fjord–not just try to figure out his father figure, or his past, or what the situation is. He saw this guy who seemed like […] he was an upright guy […] be tempted by power.

First and foremost, I find it interesting that to Caleb there is a distinction between Fjord’s power-seeking when it’s tied to learning more about himself or his past, and Fjord seeking (and being tempted by) power for power’s sake. It’s an understandable distinction to make, but it also reveals something about how Caleb views/understands power, and its acquisition. When Fjord was seeking power and knowledge as a way to learn more about his past, there was a specific, bounded purpose in his pursuit. That was, and is, a motivation that Caleb can relate to–after all, his own pursuit of power is largely motivated by him wanting to save his family from his own terrible decision. I think that Fjord’s desire for power has always been at least partially self-interested (or: Fjord’s interested in power because he spent so much of his life feeling powerless). But between Caleb projecting his understanding of power onto Fjord, and the fact that Caleb thinks of Fjord as a fundamentally “upright guy,” he hasn’t really seen the darker parts of Fjord until now.

And in that moment–[Caleb]’s very much like Trent, the man who molded him–saw for a split second in time a hunger in this guy’s eyes, and thought that it could be molded or bent for his use.

A man who has put no bounds on his pursuit of power–who does not know where his desire and temptation begins and ends–is a person who is both dangerous and vulnerable in Caleb’s view. Caleb deeply and intimately knows what it is to be Dangerous and Vulnerable. I’ve spent the past week turning the word “manipulative” around in my head. So much, that I went to look at its denotative definition.

adjective: manipulative

1. characterized by unscrupulous control of a situation or person.

I don’t disagree that Caleb (thought he) was manipulating Fjord in this moment, but I don’t think it was the favor that was the “unscrupulous” part of the manipulation. After all, while Fjord may be a man of his word, he is also on the whole (in Caleb’s mind), a Good Man. Caleb knows that it’s entirely likely that if he asks Fjord for the wrong thing he could refuse to go along with it, regardless of any pact or promise, (as Liam said, “You know, Fjord could murder Caleb later”). Caleb’s conscious goal in manipulating Fjord’s curiosity to his advantage was to obtain a favor, but the real danger of the moment was that by indulging Fjord, Caleb pushed him that much closer to the edge that Fjord has been steadily approaching over the course of this arc. Caleb doesn’t realize that the Mighty Nein genuinely care for him and want to support him, so while Caleb intended to “win” a favor from the Fjord, the real effect of Caleb’s decision to join Fjord in the sacrifice had more to do with pushing Fjord closer to being the type of person who might honor a morally questionable request.

The transactional lens through which Caleb tends to view his relationships is usually passive. It’s an instinctual derivation of his training from Trent–“the man who molded him.” This moment with Fjord is one of the first times since The Iron Shepherd’s arc that he’s actively viewed a party member through the same lens Trent viewed the Blumenthal kids. Instead of Caleb’s typical “I don’t understand how friends work,” brand of “manipulation,” this scene had Caleb think, “I am actively exploiting a weakness to my own ends.” (With a healthy serving of “I don’t know how friends work” on the side.) Caleb’s transactional understanding of interpersonal relationships has been a consistent piece of his characterization. And because it’s a perspective that’s been trained into his subconscious–and Caleb has consistently resisted any desire to move towards recovery–it’s a perspective that’s hard to break out of. But up until the most recent episode, the person who was most harmed by this outlook was Caleb himself.

He thought, “I could take a risk here, that will probably be okay. I could probably do this and not end the world, or anything. We could pull short of whatever this is going to be, and I could have a new understanding with Fjord, and I could probably pull a favor out of this.” I thought that in advance, like “[Fjord] wants to do something here, and I want to facilitate it, and have him be beholden to me for it.”

While Caleb went into the blood sacrifice with the intention and expectation that they wouldn’t see it through to its end, in the moment he ultimately leaves the decision in Fjord’s hands. When Caleb is given opportunity and reason to draw the exchange to a close, he instead pushes Fjord in order to see how far he’s willing to go in his pursuit. If the exchange had ended there, with Caleb deciding they ought to leave well enough alone, he would have still walked away with his favor. But I don’t know that they would have come to the same “understanding.” And to Caleb’s mind, it’s possible that Fjord hadn’t yet reached a point where he was “beholden” to Caleb. That final acquisition to Fjord might have been enough to tip the scales.

Caleb’s relationship with Fjord is distinct from the individual relationships he has with the rest of the group. They are more alike than I think the both of them realize. To the extent that they do realize it though, their similar approaches to solving problems has always been their most common point of connection. The extent to which Caleb and Fjord clearly don’t understand each other has also been one of their biggest points of contention. While I don’t think most of the party (outside of Nott) necessarily trusts Caleb, I think at this point most of them believe that he’s dedicated to the group. I think Fjord has come closer to reaching that point over the course of this arc, but I don’t know if he’d quite arrived there yet. Fjord has been burned and betrayed by people often enough that he likely places more stock in actions than he does in words. Caleb helping to save him from the Iron Shepherds, and putting himself on the line in Dark Tow are really the biggest examples of Caleb acting in support of Fjord/the group. Even if Caleb doesn’t fully understand Fjord’s stance on loyalty, I think he at least understands that he values action over words. It’s a risk to put the call of whether or not to continue the ritual in Fjord’s hands, but that very abdication of control increases the chance that Fjord will recognize Caleb’s sacrifice (both literally and metaphorically) as something that warrants or constitutes a debt between them. Putting the decision in Fjord’s hands also lets Caleb poke and prod at the edges of Fjord’s interest in power.

But even within the depths of Caleb’s manipulative inner monologue, a bit of sentimentality slips through. There are many things that Caleb wanted out of the exchange, most of them seemingly one-sided. But Liam lists “an understanding with Fjord,” as a distinct motivating factor. Maybe I’m reading too much into that particular word choice (but hey, that’s what I do), but I think it’s important that Caleb was looking for an understanding with Fjord, and not an understanding of or from Fjord. (Whereas I think Fjord was seeking an understanding of Caleb, just as much as he was interested in finding an understanding with Caleb.) I think that Caleb often feels like he’s on his back foot with Fjord–he hasn’t found the awkward harmony and equilibrium with him that he has with the other members of the group. They understand each other on a pragmatic level, and they both honestly like and care for the other, but there hasn’t really been mutual understanding there. And sadly, despite Fjord’s declaration that “we understand each other,” at the end, I don’t think they found it in this scene, either. For Fjord, that understanding was bound up in the symbolism of their joined hands. But, “Caleb saw no significance to cut palms touching, other than the fact that it was obvious that Fjord did.” It’s actually quite astounding that Caleb understands enough about Fjord to know that making a deliberate and definitive display of solidarity would work toward winning Fjord’s loyalty (or: would make him beholden to him), without understanding the personal and emotional significance that Fjord brings to his loyalties. I do think that Caleb and Fjord both came out of the pact with a greater understanding of each other, and how far the other is willing to go in the pursuit of power and its “reward.” But I don’t think they found a common point of understanding between each other.

I am also struck by the fact that this scene marks one of the first times Caleb has experienced remorse since he killed his parents.

[A]fter that moment, […] Caleb was disgusted with himself […] He was a product of his schooling in that moment. And part of him was like “Yes,” and the rest of him went, “You fucking piece of filth. Look at you.”

I think that there’s a lot that Caleb regrets, or that he doesn’t feel great about, but in general Caleb tends not to be particularly reflective about his darker impulses/instincts. Caleb defaults to “manipulating” the people around him, because he legitimately doesn’t know how to have interpersonal relationships that don’t involve some element of duplicity or calculated reciprocity. Similarly, he’s willing and able to be intimidating and coldly calculating when he needs to be, because those are skills and modes of operating that have become his normal. The nature of his transactional relationship towards other characters has always been predicated on relatively small, but steady demonstrations of support and power. The blood sacrifice/pact marks the first time that Caleb has chosen to manipulate his relationship with a member of the Nein via the explicit exploitation of their vulnerabilities. It’s the first time Caleb has actively approached a situation through Trent’s perspective as opposed to solving problems with Trent’s methods.

At the moment, Caleb is at a crossroads. On the one hand, the intense amount of regret, disgust and self-loathing he experienced right after making the pact with Fjord–coupled with Jester’s disappointment–may trigger an honest reckoning with himself. It might not be an immediate shift, but if some combination of Beau, Nott, and Jester are able to get him to actually be honest about his motivations and feelings, there is some potential for healthy progress. On the other hand, Caleb may (and, honestly, probably will) interpret this scene as a confirmation of his deepest suspicions that he is a “garbage person.” He might close off and refuse to engage with the others. Caleb often seems to embody a, “I’m a terrible person, may as well embrace it,” mindset where it comes to morals. If his sense of self becomes more negative after this moment, it may result in him making increasingly dubious and harmful decisions. I really have no clue what road lies ahead of this, only that it’s probably going to be really fucking painful.

Some additional thoughts that aren’t as directly related to everything above:

Liam: Ultimately he knew he would get to a point where–There’s things that he wants to do, and there’s multiple things that he might do. He’s not quite sure what he wants to do, but he has a couple of branches of things that he could do.

I really want Caleb to actually talk to the group about these branching plans, because while what I ultimately want for Caleb is for him to move on, I’m also really curious about whether the group might be able to help him find a solution that poses relatively little risk to reality, saves his parents, and allows him to maintain the relationship with the group. I don’t think that specific outcome is particularly likely. But regardless, I think the fact that Caleb’s goals are still relatively malleable means that there’s a chance to alter them.

None of those are going to happen unless he takes risks, and earns big. So there’s no reason to play it safe, after a certain point. Calculated risks, something that Caleb and Fjord have talked about for a long time. And if he dies trying to do the things he’s attempting here? That’s okay with him. He is trying to undo something disgusting and terrible. He’s willing to put his life on the line to make it happen. So he doesn’t do anything willy-nilly–he thinks, “Well this could be the end of you, but it could get you this much closer to– […] this could pull you closer to the thing you want.”

Hey, fuck me, Caleb will literally throw his life away on the slim chance he might be able to bring his parents back instead of trying to build a new one with these people who already and also love him.

And away we go!

Liam: Caleb, in that moment, could see this man, who he spent all this time with start to be tempted by power, which was always a thought that Caleb had. But he saw Fjord–not just try to figure out his father figure, or his past, or what the situation is. He saw this guy who seemed like […] he was an upright guy […] be tempted by power.

First and foremost, I find it interesting that to Caleb there is a distinction between Fjord’s power-seeking when it’s tied to learning more about himself or his past, and Fjord seeking (and being tempted by) power for power’s sake. It’s an understandable distinction to make, but it also reveals something about how Caleb views/understands power, and its acquisition. When Fjord was seeking power and knowledge as a way to learn more about his past, there was a specific, bounded purpose in his pursuit. That was, and is, a motivation that Caleb can relate to–after all, his own pursuit of power is largely motivated by him wanting to save his family from his own terrible decision. I think that Fjord’s desire for power has always been at least partially self-interested (or: Fjord’s interested in power because he spent so much of his life feeling powerless). But between Caleb projecting his understanding of power onto Fjord, and the fact that Caleb thinks of Fjord as a fundamentally “upright guy,” he hasn’t really seen the darker parts of Fjord until now.

And in that moment–[Caleb]’s very much like Trent, the man who molded him–saw for a split second in time a hunger in this guy’s eyes, and thought that it could be molded or bent for his use.

A man who has put no bounds on his pursuit of power–who does not know where his desire and temptation begins and ends–is a person who is both dangerous and vulnerable in Caleb’s view. Caleb deeply and intimately knows what it is to be Dangerous and Vulnerable. I’ve spent the past week turning the word “manipulative” around in my head. So much, that I went to look at its denotative definition.

adjective: manipulative

1. characterized by unscrupulous control of a situation or person.

I don’t disagree that Caleb (thought he) was manipulating Fjord in this moment, but I don’t think it was the favor that was the “unscrupulous” part of the manipulation. After all, while Fjord may be a man of his word, he is also on the whole (in Caleb’s mind), a Good Man. Caleb knows that it’s entirely likely that if he asks Fjord for the wrong thing he could refuse to go along with it, regardless of any pact or promise, (as Liam said, “You know, Fjord could murder Caleb later”). Caleb’s conscious goal in manipulating Fjord’s curiosity to his advantage was to obtain a favor, but the real danger of the moment was that by indulging Fjord, Caleb pushed him that much closer to the edge that Fjord has been steadily approaching over the course of this arc. Caleb doesn’t realize that the Mighty Nein genuinely care for him and want to support him, so while Caleb intended to “win” a favor from the Fjord, the real effect of Caleb’s decision to join Fjord in the sacrifice had more to do with pushing Fjord closer to being the type of person who might honor a morally questionable request.

The transactional lens through which Caleb tends to view his relationships is usually passive. It’s an instinctual derivation of his training from Trent–“the man who molded him.” This moment with Fjord is one of the first times since The Iron Shepherd’s arc that he’s actively viewed a party member through the same lens Trent viewed the Blumenthal kids. Instead of Caleb’s typical “I don’t understand how friends work,” brand of “manipulation,” this scene had Caleb think, “I am actively exploiting a weakness to my own ends.” (With a healthy serving of “I don’t know how friends work” on the side.) Caleb’s transactional understanding of interpersonal relationships has been a consistent piece of his characterization. And because it’s a perspective that’s been trained into his subconscious–and Caleb has consistently resisted any desire to move towards recovery–it’s a perspective that’s hard to break out of. But up until the most recent episode, the person who was most harmed by this outlook was Caleb himself.

He thought, “I could take a risk here, that will probably be okay. I could probably do this and not end the world, or anything. We could pull short of whatever this is going to be, and I could have a new understanding with Fjord, and I could probably pull a favor out of this.” I thought that in advance, like “[Fjord] wants to do something here, and I want to facilitate it, and have him be beholden to me for it.”

While Caleb went into the blood sacrifice with the intention and expectation that they wouldn’t see it through to its end, in the moment he ultimately leaves the decision in Fjord’s hands. When Caleb is given opportunity and reason to draw the exchange to a close, he instead pushes Fjord in order to see how far he’s willing to go in his pursuit. If the exchange had ended there, with Caleb deciding they ought to leave well enough alone, he would have still walked away with his favor. But I don’t know that they would have come to the same “understanding.” And to Caleb’s mind, it’s possible that Fjord hadn’t yet reached a point where he was “beholden” to Caleb. That final acquisition to Fjord might have been enough to tip the scales.

Caleb’s relationship with Fjord is distinct from the individual relationships he has with the rest of the group. They are more alike than I think the both of them realize. To the extent that they do realize it though, their similar approaches to solving problems has always been their most common point of connection. The extent to which Caleb and Fjord clearly don’t understand each other has also been one of their biggest points of contention. While I don’t think most of the party (outside of Nott) necessarily trusts Caleb, I think at this point most of them believe that he’s dedicated to the group. I think Fjord has come closer to reaching that point over the course of this arc, but I don’t know if he’d quite arrived there yet. Fjord has been burned and betrayed by people often enough that he likely places more stock in actions than he does in words. Caleb helping to save him from the Iron Shepherds, and putting himself on the line in Dark Tow are really the biggest examples of Caleb acting in support of Fjord/the group. Even if Caleb doesn’t fully understand Fjord’s stance on loyalty, I think he at least understands that he values action over words. It’s a risk to put the call of whether or not to continue the ritual in Fjord’s hands, but that very abdication of control increases the chance that Fjord will recognize Caleb’s sacrifice (both literally and metaphorically) as something that warrants or constitutes a debt between them. Putting the decision in Fjord’s hands also lets Caleb poke and prod at the edges of Fjord’s interest in power.

But even within the depths of Caleb’s manipulative inner monologue, a bit of sentimentality slips through. There are many things that Caleb wanted out of the exchange, most of them seemingly one-sided. But Liam lists “an understanding with Fjord,” as a distinct motivating factor. Maybe I’m reading too much into that particular word choice (but hey, that’s what I do), but I think it’s important that Caleb was looking for an understanding with Fjord, and not an understanding of or from Fjord. (Whereas I think Fjord was seeking an understanding of Caleb, just as much as he was interested in finding an understanding with Caleb.) I think that Caleb often feels like he’s on his back foot with Fjord–he hasn’t found the awkward harmony and equilibrium with him that he has with the other members of the group. They understand each other on a pragmatic level, and they both honestly like and care for the other, but there hasn’t really been mutual understanding there. And sadly, despite Fjord’s declaration that “we understand each other,” at the end, I don’t think they found it in this scene, either. For Fjord, that understanding was bound up in the symbolism of their joined hands. But, “Caleb saw no significance to cut palms touching, other than the fact that it was obvious that Fjord did.” It’s actually quite astounding that Caleb understands enough about Fjord to know that making a deliberate and definitive display of solidarity would work toward winning Fjord’s loyalty (or: would make him beholden to him), without understanding the personal and emotional significance that Fjord brings to his loyalties. I do think that Caleb and Fjord both came out of the pact with a greater understanding of each other, and how far the other is willing to go in the pursuit of power and its “reward.” But I don’t think they found a common point of understanding between each other.

I am also struck by the fact that this scene marks one of the first times Caleb has experienced remorse since he killed his parents.

[A]fter that moment, […] Caleb was disgusted with himself […] He was a product of his schooling in that moment. And part of him was like “Yes,” and the rest of him went, “You fucking piece of filth. Look at you.”

I think that there’s a lot that Caleb regrets, or that he doesn’t feel great about, but in general Caleb tends not to be particularly reflective about his darker impulses/instincts. Caleb defaults to “manipulating” the people around him, because he legitimately doesn’t know how to have interpersonal relationships that don’t involve some element of duplicity or calculated reciprocity. Similarly, he’s willing and able to be intimidating and coldly calculating when he needs to be, because those are skills and modes of operating that have become his normal. The nature of his transactional relationship towards other characters has always been predicated on relatively small, but steady demonstrations of support and power. The blood sacrifice/pact marks the first time that Caleb has chosen to manipulate his relationship with a member of the Nein via the explicit exploitation of their vulnerabilities. It’s the first time Caleb has actively approached a situation through Trent’s perspective as opposed to solving problems with Trent’s methods.

At the moment, Caleb is at a crossroads. On the one hand, the intense amount of regret, disgust and self-loathing he experienced right after making the pact with Fjord–coupled with Jester’s disappointment–may trigger an honest reckoning with himself. It might not be an immediate shift, but if some combination of Beau, Nott, and Jester are able to get him to actually be honest about his motivations and feelings, there is some potential for healthy progress. On the other hand, Caleb may (and, honestly, probably will) interpret this scene as a confirmation of his deepest suspicions that he is a “garbage person.” He might close off and refuse to engage with the others. Caleb often seems to embody a, “I’m a terrible person, may as well embrace it,” mindset where it comes to morals. If his sense of self becomes more negative after this moment, it may result in him making increasingly dubious and harmful decisions. I really have no clue what road lies ahead of this, only that it’s probably going to be really fucking painful.

Some additional thoughts that aren’t as directly related to everything above:

Liam: Ultimately he knew he would get to a point where–There’s things that he wants to do, and there’s multiple things that he might do. He’s not quite sure what he wants to do, but he has a couple of branches of things that he could do.

I really want Caleb to actually talk to the group about these branching plans, because while what I ultimately want for Caleb is for him to move on, I’m also really curious about whether the group might be able to help him find a solution that poses relatively little risk to reality, saves his parents, and allows him to maintain the relationship with the group. I don’t think that specific outcome is particularly likely. But regardless, I think the fact that Caleb’s goals are still relatively malleable means that there’s a chance to alter them.

None of those are going to happen unless he takes risks, and earns big. So there’s no reason to play it safe, after a certain point. Calculated risks, something that Caleb and Fjord have talked about for a long time. And if he dies trying to do the things he’s attempting here? That’s okay with him. He is trying to undo something disgusting and terrible. He’s willing to put his life on the line to make it happen. So he doesn’t do anything willy-nilly–he thinks, “Well this could be the end of you, but it could get you this much closer to– […] this could pull you closer to the thing you want.”

Hey, fuck me, Caleb will literally throw his life away on the slim chance he might be able to bring his parents back instead of trying to build a new one with these people who already and also love him.
trail.content_abstract:
[Spoilers for C2E44]

Here it is! My entirely-too-long break down of pretty much everything that came out of Liam O’Brien’s mouth pertaining to the blood sacrifice/pact at the end of last week’s episode. 

Before we begin, I want to be clear that this is an analysis specifically about Caleb’s perspective during the scene in question. My thoughts about the scene as a whole, and Fjord’s role in it–and how that influences Caleb’s part in it–are more complicated (and I’ve already written about it a bit). Caleb’s motivations in this scene were obviously unhealthy, but I don’t think that Fjord was without agency or fault in this exchange, and I think that Fjord had equally complicated motivations as Caleb (if not necessarily as consciously manipulative).

This is pretty much just a paragraph-by-paragraph analysis of what Liam said on Talks Tuesday night, so I’ll be quoting chunks of it and then dumping my thoughts all over it. (And it’s below a cut because of my classic verbosity). 

And away we go!

summary: Hiya! I'm here for your Critical Role content which I love, but I did have a question. People are always talking about Fjord's...
question: Hiya! I'm here for your Critical Role content which I love, but I did have a question. People are always talking about Fjord's accent, specifically how it changes in certain moments, but because english isn't my first language, I can't really tell the accents apart and I have no idea what's going on. Any chance you could explain a little maybe?
answer:
Hoo boy I’m not a linguist or a vocal coach by any stretch of the imagination, but I think I can help you get the basics down at least!

Fjord has two ‘accents’ that we’ve seen in the game. (Not counting ones that he puts on as a genuine disguise, since those are clearly meant to be read as ‘fake’.)

One is a mimicry of Vandren’s mode of speech, the Southern (United States) accent, and one that is how Fjord actually speaks, or the British English accent.

Best way to differentiate between them is to familiarize yourself with the way they sound and I think this video can help you with that!

Now obviously there are going to be regional differences to both types of accents but, again, I’m not a linguist so I can’t really help you there gfhdkjgf BUT!!! This should be enough information to help you tell when he switches accents in-game. :D

I hope this helped!
